title: 109_s2475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is established with 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Members must have a commitment to research or study. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is established with 23 members appointed by key government officials. Members must have a commitment to research or study and possess expertise in various areas related to American Latino life, art, history, and culture. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is established with 23 members appointed by key government officials. Members must have expertise in areas related to American Latino life, art, history, and culture. The functions of the Commission are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is tasked with submitting a report to the President and Congress on a plan for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. This includes developing fundraising plans and examining issues such as collection availability, impact on regional museums, and possible locations for the Museum. The Commission is responsible for submitting a report on establishing a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. This includes considering possible locations, governance structure, and community engagement. Recommendations will be submitted to relevant House and Senate committees for consideration. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, involving individuals dedicated to American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Interior will provide administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses. The Commission must submit reports within 18 months and terminate 30 days after submission. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission is set at $2.1 million for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008.
